%%% INTRO

There are lots of commands in git and you often can achieve your goal in several different ways. Usually I manage to get my stuff done in one way or another with just few commands like rebase, reset, cherry-pick. Sometimes I felt I was doing it in an ineffective way, like for instance squashing all commits into a single one so that itâ€™s easier to rebase afterward ğŸ™ˆ Even though I knew that rebase --onto would be useful, I never took the time to man itâ€¦ until recently.

I guess now is a good time to write something about it. Actually I just want to inaugurate my blog with this first post ğŸ˜ (any reason is a good reason â˜ï¸)

So in which cases can the --onto option be useful?

It can help you when:

  • you want to cherry-pick multiples commits
  • you created a branch from the â€˜wrongâ€™ one and you want to move all the commits starting from the â€˜rightâ€™ branch
  • you want to delete a range of commits Actually, it all comes down to the same thing: bring a range of commits somewhere else

âš ï¸ I assume you have basic knowledge about git, and that you are familiar with its index, working tree as well as commands like reset, cherry-pick

Lets begin with a little reminder about how rebase works in its simplest form.

rebase

git rebase upstream [branch]

Let say that you are on branch B (HEAD â†’ B) and you run git rebase A First the index and working tree are reset to A. This is exactly like running git reset --hard A except that changes to tracked files in the working tree are saved somewhere for later use. After that, git will apply those saved commits one by one. This is like â€œcherry-pickingâ€ those commits.

Note that you donâ€™t have to be on branch B, git can perform a checkout B for you when you specify the 2nd arg branch â†’ git rebase A B So git rebase A is just a short hand for git rebase A B when you are already on B branch

To summarize all of the following scenarios are equivalents: %% l23 from firstdraft

rebase â€”onto ?

git rebase --onto newbase upstream [branch]

The only difference is that git will reset to newbase instead of upstream and will then applies commits between upstream (exluded) and branch (included)
